overview: A mild viral upper respiratory infection causing nasal and throat symptoms; self-limiting in most people.
symptoms: runny nose; sore throat; cough; sneezing; mild fever; nasal congestion
cautions: Avoid spreading to vulnerable people; rest and hydration; seek care if high fever or breathing difficulty
medications: Symptomatic: analgesics/antipyretics (as needed), decongestants, throat lozenges (use as directed)
prevention: Hand hygiene; avoid close contact with sick people; respiratory etiquette; stay home when symptomatic
treatment: Rest; fluids; symptomatic relief; monitor for bacterial complications; seek medical care for severe or prolonged symptoms

overview: An acute viral respiratory illness caused by influenza viruses; can cause seasonal outbreaks and severe disease in high-risk groups.
symptoms: sudden fever; chills; cough; sore throat; muscle aches; fatigue; headache
cautions: High-risk groups (elderly, pregnant, immunocompromised) should seek early care; watch for breathing difficulty or rapid deterioration
medications: Antivirals (oseltamivir/zanamivir) when prescribed early; supportive care (antipyretics, fluids)
prevention: Annual influenza vaccination; hand hygiene; avoid sick contacts; cough etiquette
treatment: Antiviral therapy when indicated and started early; supportive care; hospitalization if severe respiratory compromise

overview: Respiratory illness caused by SARS-CoV-2, with a range from mild to severe disease and potential systemic effects.
symptoms: fever; cough; shortness of breath; fatigue; loss of taste or smell; sore throat; myalgia
cautions: Isolate when positive; protect vulnerable individuals; seek immediate care for breathing difficulty or chest pain
medications: Supportive care; antivirals or other agents per guidelines when indicated; symptomatic medications
prevention: Vaccination; masks in high-risk settings; ventilation; hand hygiene; testing and isolation when exposed or symptomatic
treatment: Supportive care; guided by severity—home isolation for mild cases, antivirals/monoclonals per protocol, oxygen/hospital care for severe disease

overview: Bacterial pharyngitis usually caused by Group A Streptococcus; presents with sore throat and fever.
symptoms: sore throat (severe); fever; tender cervical lymph nodes; tonsillar exudates; absence of cough
cautions: Confirm with rapid antigen test or culture before antibiotics; untreated can lead to complications like rheumatic fever
medications: Antibiotics (e.g., penicillin or amoxicillin) when bacterial infection confirmed; analgesics for symptom relief
prevention: Avoid sharing utensils; hand hygiene; stay home until 24 hours after antibiotics start
treatment: Antibiotic therapy when indicated; supportive analgesia and hydration; follow-up if symptoms worsen

overview: Infection of the lung parenchyma that can be caused by bacteria, viruses, or fungi; severity varies widely.
symptoms: fever; productive cough; shortness of breath; chest pain; fatigue
cautions: Seek urgent care for high fever, rapid breathing, chest pain, or low oxygen levels
medications: Antibiotics for bacterial causes; antivirals for specific viral causes when indicated; supportive care (oxygen if needed)
prevention: Vaccination (influenza, pneumococcal where indicated); smoking cessation; hand hygiene; timely treatment of respiratory infections
treatment: Antibiotics for bacterial pneumonia guided by severity and likely pathogen; oxygen therapy and hospital care for severe cases; physiotherapy as needed

overview: A chronic infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, primarily affecting the lungs but can be systemic.
symptoms: persistent cough (>2 weeks); weight loss; night sweats; fever; hemoptysis
cautions: TB is contagious—notify public health; adhere strictly to long-term treatment to prevent resistance
medications: Long-course anti-tubercular therapy (multiple drugs under programmatic supervision)
prevention: Screening in high-risk groups; BCG vaccination in some regions; airborne precautions when infectious
treatment: Long-term multi-drug therapy under medical supervision; public health reporting and contact tracing

overview: Inflammation of the bronchi, commonly viral; presents with cough and sometimes sputum production.
symptoms: cough (productive or dry); chest discomfort; mild fever; wheeze in some cases
cautions: Seek care if high fever, difficulty breathing, or symptoms lasting >3 weeks
medications: Symptomatic care: bronchodilators for wheeze, cough suppressants if needed, analgesics
prevention: Avoid smoking; hand hygiene; vaccination for influenza to reduce risk
treatment: Supportive care (rest, fluids, bronchodilators if wheezy); antibiotics only if bacterial infection suspected

overview: A chronic inflammatory airway disease causing variable airflow obstruction and bronchospasm, often triggered by allergens or infections.
symptoms: wheezing; shortness of breath; chest tightness; coughing (worse at night or early morning)
cautions: Have an action plan for attacks; seek emergency care for severe breathing difficulty or cyanosis
medications: Inhaled bronchodilators (short-acting), inhaled corticosteroids for control, leukotriene modifiers as prescribed
prevention: Avoid known triggers (allergens, smoke); inhaler technique education; allergy control; vaccination
treatment: Controller therapy with inhaled corticosteroids and reliever inhalers for exacerbations; action plan and specialist review for uncontrolled asthma

overview: A progressive lung disease (emphysema and chronic bronchitis) linked to smoking and other exposures, causing airflow limitation.
symptoms: chronic cough with sputum; progressive dyspnea; wheeze; frequent respiratory infections
cautions: Smoking cessation is critical; vaccinations recommended; seek care for acute exacerbations
medications: Bronchodilators (short/long acting), inhaled corticosteroids in selected patients, oxygen therapy for hypoxemia
prevention: Avoid smoking and pollutants; pulmonary rehabilitation; influenza and pneumococcal vaccination
treatment: Smoking cessation, bronchodilator therapy, pulmonary rehab, long-term oxygen in advanced disease, antibiotics/steroids for exacerbations

overview: An allergic inflammation of the nasal mucosa triggered by allergens such as pollen or dust mites.
symptoms: sneezing; nasal congestion; itchy/runny nose; itchy eyes; post-nasal drip
cautions: Avoid known allergens; seek care if breathing difficulty or severe sinus symptoms
medications: Antihistamines; intranasal corticosteroids; nasal saline rinses
prevention: Allergen avoidance; hypoallergenic bedding; nasal hygiene; immunotherapy for selected patients
treatment: Antihistamines and intranasal steroids for symptom control; allergen immunotherapy when indicated

overview: Inflammation/infection of the paranasal sinuses causing nasal blockage, facial pain, and discharge.
symptoms: facial pain/pressure; nasal congestion; purulent nasal discharge; reduced smell; cough
cautions: Seek care for severe facial pain, high fever, or symptoms >10 days without improvement
medications: Analgesics, nasal saline, intranasal corticosteroids; antibiotics if bacterial sinusitis suspected
prevention: Avoid upper respiratory infections; manage allergies; nasal hygiene
treatment: Supportive care; antibiotics when bacterial infection likely; refer ENT for chronic or recurrent disease

overview: Infection or inflammation of the middle ear, common in children, associated with ear pain and sometimes fever.
symptoms: ear pain; hearing difficulty; fever; irritability (children); ear discharge if perforation
cautions: Prompt evaluation in young children; watch for complications like mastoiditis
medications: Analgesics for pain; antibiotics when indicated (age and severity dependent)
prevention: Reduce exposure to respiratory infections; breastfeeding in infants reduces risk; avoid smoke exposure
treatment: Pain control, watchful waiting in some pediatric cases, antibiotics when indicated, ENT follow-up for recurrent disease

overview: A neurological headache disorder characterized by recurrent moderate-to-severe headaches often with pulsatile quality and sensory sensitivity.
symptoms: intense unilateral headache; nausea/vomiting; photophobia; phonophobia; aura in some
cautions: Seek care for sudden severe headache, neurological deficits, or new pattern of headaches
medications: Acute treatment: triptans, NSAIDs, antiemetics as appropriate (prescription) ; prophylactic agents for frequent attacks
prevention: Identify and avoid triggers (sleep, diet, stress); maintain regular sleep/eating; hydration
treatment: Acute abortive therapy tailored to patient; preventive medications and lifestyle measures for frequent migraines; specialist referral for refractory cases

overview: The most common primary headache, often described as band-like pressure around the head; usually less severe than migraine.
symptoms: bilateral pressing/tightening head pain; mild to moderate intensity; not aggravated by routine activity
cautions: Avoid medication overuse (frequent analgesic use can worsen headaches)
medications: Analgesics such as acetaminophen or NSAIDs (use as directed) ; non-pharmacologic measures
prevention: Stress management; ergonomic adjustments; regular sleep and hydration
treatment: Analgesics for acute pain, relaxation techniques, physiotherapy, and addressing triggers for recurrent cases

overview: Inflammation of the stomach and intestines commonly due to viruses, bacteria, or parasites; causes diarrhoea and vomiting.
symptoms: nausea; vomiting; watery diarrhoea; abdominal cramps; fever in some cases
cautions: Prevent dehydration; seek care for severe vomiting, bloody diarrhoea, or signs of dehydration
medications: Oral rehydration solutions; antimotility agents in adults when appropriate; antibiotics for certain bacterial causes
prevention: Hand hygiene; safe food handling; clean water; avoid contaminated food/water
treatment: Rehydration; dietary management; antimicrobials only when indicated by pathogen; seek care for severe dehydration or bloody diarrhoea

overview: Illness caused by ingestion of contaminated food or toxins, leading to acute gastrointestinal symptoms.
symptoms: nausea; vomiting; diarrhoea; abdominal pain; fever in some cases
cautions: Report outbreaks; seek care for persistent vomiting, bloody stools, or severe dehydration
medications: Supportive care with rehydration; antibiotics only when specific bacterial pathogens require it
prevention: Safe food handling and storage; cook foods thoroughly; avoid cross-contamination; clean water
treatment: Supportive care and rehydration; targeted antibiotics if indicated by testing; hospital care for severe cases

overview: Inflammation of the stomach lining due to infection (eg H. pylori), medications, alcohol, or stress.
symptoms: epigastric pain; nausea; vomiting; bloating; loss of appetite
cautions: Avoid NSAIDs and alcohol if gastritis suspected; seek prompt care for severe pain or bleeding
medications: Antacids; H2 blockers; proton pump inhibitors; eradication therapy for H. pylori when diagnosed
prevention: Avoid NSAIDs and excessive alcohol; balanced diet; treat H. pylori if present
treatment: Acid suppression (PPI/H2 blocker), remove offending agents, treat H. pylori when present, dietary modification

overview: Ulceration of the stomach or duodenal lining often related to H. pylori infection or NSAID use.
symptoms: burning epigastric pain (may improve/worsen with food); nausea; bloating; possible GI bleeding
cautions: Seek urgent care for black/tarry stools or vomiting blood; avoid NSAIDs if ulcers suspected
medications: PPI therapy; H. pylori eradication regimens when indicated; avoid NSAIDs
prevention: Avoid smoking and NSAIDs; treat H. pylori infection; healthy eating habits
treatment: Acid suppression with PPIs, eradicate H. pylori when present, stop NSAIDs, surgical management for complications

overview: Chronic reflux of stomach acid into the esophagus causing heartburn and regurgitation.
symptoms: heartburn; regurgitation; chest discomfort; chronic cough or hoarseness in some
cautions: Seek care for difficulty swallowing, weight loss, or bleeding; avoid long-term unsupervised PPI use
medications: Antacids for symptom relief; PPIs for persistent symptoms; lifestyle measures
prevention: Avoid trigger foods; elevate head of bed; weight management; avoid late meals and smoking
treatment: Lifestyle changes, acid suppression (PPIs), referral for endoscopy if alarm features

overview: A functional gastrointestinal disorder with recurrent abdominal pain and altered bowel habits without structural disease.
symptoms: abdominal pain; bloating; constipation and/or diarrhoea; mucus in stool
cautions: Rule out organic causes if alarm features present (weight loss, bleeding)
medications: Symptom-targeted therapy: antispasmodics, fibre supplements, laxatives or antidiarrheals as appropriate
prevention: Dietary modification (low FODMAP for some); stress management; regular exercise
treatment: Diet and lifestyle adjustments, pharmacotherapy for dominant symptoms, psychological therapies for some patients

overview: A chronic inflammatory bowel disease affecting any part of the GI tract with transmural inflammation.
symptoms: abdominal pain; diarrhoea (may be bloody); weight loss; fatigue; fever
cautions: Requires specialist management; risk of strictures, fistulae and nutritional deficiencies
medications: Aminosalicylates, corticosteroids for flares, immunomodulators and biologics for maintenance as prescribed
prevention: No single prevention; smoking cessation may reduce risk of milder disease; vaccination as recommended
treatment: Induction therapy for flares with steroids, maintenance with immunosuppressants/biologics, surgery for complications

overview: A chronic inflammatory disease limited to the colon and rectum causing bloody diarrhoea and urgency.
symptoms: bloody diarrhoea; abdominal pain; urgency; weight loss; fever in severe cases
cautions: Requires gastroenterology follow-up; monitor for colorectal cancer with long-standing disease
medications: 5-ASA agents, corticosteroids for flares, immunomodulators or biologics for moderate-severe disease
prevention: No proven prevention; regular monitoring and vaccinations as recommended
treatment: Medical induction and maintenance therapy tailored to severity; surgery (colectomy) for refractory or complicated disease

overview: A viral liver infection transmitted via the fecal-oral route, usually self-limited.
symptoms: fever; malaise; anorexia; nausea; jaundice; dark urine; pale stools
cautions: Reportable disease in many regions; maintain hygiene to prevent spread
medications: Supportive care; no specific antivirals for most cases
prevention: Hepatitis A vaccination; safe food and water practices; good hand hygiene
treatment: Supportive care, rest, hydration; rarely hospitalization for fulminant hepatitis

overview: A viral infection of the liver that can be acute or chronic, transmitted via blood and bodily fluids.
symptoms: fatigue; jaundice; abdominal pain; dark urine; joint pain; sometimes asymptomatic
cautions: Chronic hepatitis B requires monitoring for liver damage and HCC; vaccination prevents infection
medications: Antivirals for chronic hepatitis B when indicated (tenofovir, entecavir) under specialist care
prevention: Hepatitis B vaccination; safe injection practices; safe sex practices
treatment: Antiviral therapy for chronic cases per specialist guidance; monitoring for liver disease; supportive care for acute infection

overview: A viral liver infection transmitted mainly by blood exposure; often becomes chronic and can cause liver cirrhosis.
symptoms: fatigue; jaundice; abdominal pain; dark urine; often asymptomatic for years
cautions: Screen at-risk populations; treatment can cure most cases with antivirals
medications: Direct-acting antivirals (DAAs) under specialist supervision; avoid alcohol to reduce liver damage
prevention: Avoid sharing needles; safe medical practices and blood screening; harm reduction services
treatment: Curative antiviral regimens (DAAs) prescribed by specialists; liver monitoring and lifestyle measures

overview: Inflammation of the pancreas that can be acute or chronic, often related to gallstones or alcohol use.
symptoms: severe upper abdominal pain radiating to back; nausea; vomiting; fever
cautions: Seek emergency care for severe abdominal pain and vomiting; can be life-threatening
medications: Supportive hospital care; IV fluids; pain management; treat underlying cause
prevention: Limit alcohol; maintain healthy triglycerides; manage gallstones
treatment: Hospitalization; fluid resuscitation; pain control; nutritional support; surgery or ERCP if indicated

overview: Solid deposits in the gallbladder that can cause pain or complications when obstructing ducts.
symptoms: episodic right upper quadrant pain; nausea; vomiting; pain after fatty meals
cautions: Seek medical care for severe or persistent pain or jaundice
medications: Pain relief (NSAIDs); surgical removal of gallbladder (cholecystectomy) if symptomatic
prevention: Maintain healthy weight; balanced diet; avoid crash dieting
treatment: Surgical (laparoscopic cholecystectomy) for symptomatic stones; pain control and supportive care

overview: Inflammation of the gallbladder often due to gallstones blocking the duct.
symptoms: right upper quadrant pain; fever; nausea; vomiting
cautions: Seek urgent care; risk of perforation or sepsis
medications: Antibiotics; pain control; eventual cholecystectomy
prevention: Healthy diet; manage cholesterol and weight; avoid fatty foods
treatment: Hospital management with IV fluids, antibiotics, and surgical removal of gallbladder

overview: Infection of the urinary tract, most commonly bladder infection in females.
symptoms: burning urination; frequency; urgency; suprapubic pain; sometimes fever
cautions: Increase fluid intake; seek care for fever, flank pain, or recurrent infections
medications: Antibiotics tailored to culture results; analgesics for dysuria
prevention: Good hydration; urinate after intercourse; proper hygiene
treatment: Antibiotic therapy per sensitivity; manage risk factors for recurrence

overview: Kidney infection often ascending from bladder; more serious than cystitis.
symptoms: fever; flank pain; nausea; vomiting; dysuria
cautions: Needs prompt medical care; can progress to sepsis if untreated
medications: Antibiotics (oral or IV depending on severity) under medical supervision
prevention: Prevent UTIs; adequate hydration; treat underlying causes
treatment: Hospitalization for severe cases; IV antibiotics; fluids; monitoring renal function

overview: Hard mineral deposits in the urinary tract causing pain and obstruction.
symptoms: severe flank pain; hematuria; nausea; vomiting
cautions: Seek emergency care for uncontrolled pain or infection signs
medications: Pain relief (NSAIDs, opioids if severe); alpha blockers to facilitate passage; surgical removal if needed
prevention: Hydration; reduce dietary salt and oxalate; manage calcium intake
treatment: Pain management; stone passage facilitation; lithotripsy or surgical removal as indicated

overview: Sudden decrease in kidney function due to dehydration, medications, or underlying illness.
symptoms: reduced urine output; swelling; confusion; fatigue
cautions: Identify and treat cause early; monitor fluid balance
medications: Supportive care; stop nephrotoxic drugs; dialysis if severe
prevention: Stay hydrated; manage chronic diseases; avoid unnecessary nephrotoxins
treatment: Hospital management; treat cause; dialysis for severe cases until recovery

overview: Progressive loss of kidney function over time, often due to diabetes or hypertension.
symptoms: fatigue; swelling; nausea; reduced urine output; high BP
cautions: Monitor kidney function regularly; control blood sugar and BP
medications: Medications to control BP and diabetes; dietary management; dialysis in late stages
prevention: Healthy diet; control BP/diabetes; avoid nephrotoxins
treatment: Disease management, slow progression through BP/sugar control, dialysis or transplant for end-stage

overview: Involuntary leakage of urine, various causes (stress, urge, overflow).
symptoms: urine leakage; urgency; frequency
cautions: Address underlying cause; can affect quality of life but not dangerous
medications: Bladder training; pelvic floor exercises; medications or surgical options per type
prevention: Maintain healthy weight; avoid bladder irritants; pelvic floor exercises
treatment: Behavioral therapy, medications (antimuscarinics, beta-3 agonists), surgery when indicated

overview: Inflammation of the prostate, acute or chronic; bacterial or non-bacterial.
symptoms: pelvic pain; painful urination; urinary difficulty; fever (acute)
cautions: Seek medical care for high fever or urinary retention
medications: Antibiotics for bacterial type; alpha blockers and pain relief for chronic cases
prevention: Hydration; avoid prolonged sitting; safe sexual practices
treatment: Antibiotic therapy if bacterial; pain management; physiotherapy for chronic pain type

overview: Noncancerous enlargement of the prostate causing urinary symptoms in men.
symptoms: difficulty urinating; weak stream; nocturia; incomplete emptying
cautions: Seek care for urinary retention or blood in urine
medications: Alpha blockers; 5-alpha-reductase inhibitors; surgery for refractory cases
prevention: Healthy weight; avoid late-night fluids; monitor urinary function
treatment: Medication management; minimally invasive or surgical procedures if severe

overview: A common sexually transmitted infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.
symptoms: often asymptomatic; urethral discharge; dysuria; pelvic pain
cautions: Untreated infection may cause infertility; test and treat partners
medications: Antibiotics (azithromycin or doxycycline) under medical supervision
prevention: Safe sex; regular screening; partner notification
treatment: Antibiotic treatment of patient and partners; retesting to confirm cure

overview: Bacterial STI caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, can infect genital, rectal, and throat areas.
symptoms: discharge; painful urination; pelvic pain; sometimes asymptomatic
cautions: Requires antibiotic treatment; resistance is rising globally
medications: Dual antibiotic therapy per guidelines
prevention: Safe sex; regular STI screening
treatment: Antibiotic therapy guided by susceptibility; partner treatment and follow-up testing

overview: Bacterial STI caused by Treponema pallidum with multiple stages and systemic effects.
symptoms: painless genital ulcer (chancre); rash; fever; lymphadenopathy
cautions: Early diagnosis and treatment prevent complications; notify partners
medications: Penicillin-based antibiotic therapy
prevention: Safe sex; routine screening in high-risk groups
treatment: Antibiotic treatment (penicillin) appropriate to disease stage; follow-up testing

overview: Common viral STI that can cause genital warts and some cancers.
symptoms: genital warts (some strains); often asymptomatic
cautions: Vaccination prevents oncogenic strains; seek care for warts or abnormal Pap test
medications: No antiviral cure; wart treatments (topical, cryotherapy)
prevention: HPV vaccination; safe sex; regular Pap screening
treatment: Wart removal if present; cancer screening and management as indicated

overview: Human Immunodeficiency Virus causes progressive immune deficiency if untreated.
symptoms: fever; weight loss; night sweats; opportunistic infections; chronic fatigue
cautions: Strict adherence to therapy prevents progression; practice safe sex
medications: Antiretroviral therapy (ART) lifelong under medical supervision
prevention: Safe sex; sterile needles; HIV testing and early treatment
treatment: Combination ART with monitoring; management of opportunistic infections; nutritional support

overview: Inflammation of the conjunctiva due to infection or allergy; contagious in infectious cases.
symptoms: eye redness; tearing; discharge; itching; foreign body sensation
cautions: Avoid touching eyes; maintain hygiene; avoid contact lens use during infection
medications: Antibiotic drops if bacterial; antihistamines if allergic; supportive care
prevention: Hand hygiene; avoid sharing towels; manage allergies
treatment: Topical antibiotics if bacterial; antihistamines if allergic; supportive care for viral cases

overview: A group of eye diseases causing optic nerve damage, often associated with raised intraocular pressure.
symptoms: gradual vision loss; eye pain (acute); halos around lights
cautions: Requires lifelong follow-up; untreated leads to blindness
medications: Eye drops to lower pressure; laser or surgery if indicated
prevention: Regular eye exams; control systemic risk factors
treatment: Medical therapy to lower IOP; laser/surgical interventions for uncontrolled cases

overview: Clouding of the eye lens leading to visual impairment, usually age-related.
symptoms: blurred vision; glare; poor night vision; faded colors
cautions: Seek ophthalmology evaluation for visual decline
medications: No medical cure; surgery is definitive treatment
prevention: Protect eyes from UV light; manage diabetes; avoid smoking
treatment: Surgical lens replacement when vision affects daily life

overview: Retinal blood vessel damage from chronic high blood sugar leading to vision loss.
symptoms: blurred vision; floaters; vision loss; poor night vision
cautions: Regular eye screening essential; control blood sugar and BP
medications: No medications reverse it; laser therapy or injections slow progression
prevention: Strict glycemic control; regular ophthalmic exams
treatment: Laser photocoagulation or intravitreal therapy to stabilize vision; manage diabetes aggressively

overview: Infection of the outer ear canal, often after water exposure.
symptoms: ear pain; itching; discharge; hearing loss
cautions: Avoid water entry until healed; seek care for severe pain or swelling
medications: Topical antibiotic drops; analgesics
prevention: Keep ears dry; avoid inserting objects; dry ears after swimming
treatment: Topical antibiotic-steroid drops; pain relief; ENT referral for severe or chronic cases

overview: Inflammatory skin condition with itching and rash, often chronic or allergic.
symptoms: itchy rash; redness; dryness; cracking; sometimes oozing
cautions: Avoid scratching; maintain skin moisture; avoid triggers
medications: Topical corticosteroids; emollients; antihistamines for itching
prevention: Regular moisturization; avoid irritants; control allergens
treatment: Topical therapy; systemic medications for severe cases; patient education on skin care

overview: Chronic immune-mediated skin disease causing scaly plaques.
symptoms: red patches with silvery scales; itching; joint pain (psoriatic arthritis)
cautions: Not contagious; monitor for joint involvement; stress can worsen
medications: Topical steroids; vitamin D analogs; biologic agents for severe disease
prevention: Avoid skin injury and stress; maintain moisturization; avoid smoking
treatment: Topical/systemic treatments per severity; phototherapy; biologics for severe cases

overview: Common skin condition due to follicular blockage and inflammation.
symptoms: pimples; blackheads; whiteheads; cysts on face, back, or chest
cautions: Avoid picking lesions; some medications are teratogenic (consult clinician)
medications: Topical retinoids; benzoyl peroxide; oral antibiotics; isotretinoin for severe cases
prevention: Gentle cleansing; balanced diet; avoid oily cosmetics
treatment: Stepwise treatment from topical to systemic; monitor for side effects with retinoids

overview: Bacterial infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, often due to Staphylococcus or Streptococcus.
symptoms: redness; warmth; swelling; pain; sometimes fever
cautions: Mark borders to monitor spread; seek urgent care if spreading rapidly or systemic symptoms
medications: Antibiotics (oral or IV depending on severity); analgesics
prevention: Prompt wound care; hygiene; manage chronic conditions like diabetes
treatment: Antibiotic therapy; limb elevation; pain control; hospital care for severe infections

overview: Superficial contagious bacterial skin infection common in children.
symptoms: honey-colored crusted lesions on face or limbs; itching
cautions: Highly contagious; avoid close contact until treated
medications: Topical or oral antibiotics as prescribed
prevention: Hygiene; avoid sharing towels; early treatment of skin lesions
treatment: Topical antibiotics; oral antibiotics for widespread cases; hygiene measures

overview: Reactivation of latent varicella-zoster virus causing painful vesicular rash along dermatomes.
symptoms: painful rash; tingling; burning sensation; blistering; possible postherpetic neuralgia
cautions: Seek care early to start antivirals; contagious to unvaccinated individuals
medications: Antivirals (acyclovir, valacyclovir) if started early; pain management
prevention: Varicella-zoster vaccination (older adults); avoid contact with unvaccinated
treatment: Antiviral therapy within 72 hours of rash onset; pain management; supportive skin care

overview: Viral infection causing oral or genital blisters; recurrent.
symptoms: painful blisters or ulcers; tingling before outbreaks
cautions: Avoid contact during outbreaks; lifelong latency possible
medications: Antiviral therapy (acyclovir, valacyclovir) for outbreaks or suppression
prevention: Safe sex; avoid kissing during oral lesions; manage triggers
treatment: Antiviral treatment during outbreaks; suppressive therapy for frequent recurrences

overview: A highly contagious viral illness causing rash and fever; preventable by vaccination.
symptoms: fever; cough; runny nose; conjunctivitis; rash starting on face and spreading
cautions: Report suspected cases; isolate to prevent spread; dangerous in malnourished children
medications: Supportive care (fluids, fever control); vitamin A supplementation
prevention: MMR vaccination; isolation of cases; good nutrition
treatment: Supportive management; treat complications such as pneumonia or dehydration

overview: Viral infection primarily affecting salivary glands; preventable by MMR vaccine.
symptoms: fever; swollen tender parotid glands; headache; malaise
cautions: Avoid close contact while contagious; complications include orchitis and meningitis
medications: Supportive care (analgesics, hydration)
prevention: MMR vaccination; hygiene; avoid sharing utensils
treatment: Supportive care; manage complications symptomatically

overview: Generally mild viral illness but causes severe congenital infection if acquired in pregnancy.
symptoms: mild fever; rash; lymphadenopathy; joint pain
cautions: Avoid exposure during pregnancy; vaccinate before childbearing age
medications: Supportive; no specific antiviral
prevention: MMR vaccination; avoid exposure in pregnancy
treatment: Supportive treatment; public-health notification

overview: Highly contagious viral infection causing itchy vesicular rash; usually in childhood.
symptoms: fever; malaise; vesicular rash in crops; itching
cautions: Avoid scratching to prevent infection; isolate until crusted lesions
medications: Antihistamines; antivirals (acyclovir) in high-risk cases
prevention: Varicella vaccination; avoid contact with infected individuals
treatment: Supportive care; antivirals for severe or immunocompromised cases

overview: Bacterial respiratory infection causing severe paroxysmal cough; dangerous for infants.
symptoms: paroxysmal cough; inspiratory ‘whoop’; vomiting after coughing
cautions: Highly contagious—notify health authority; vaccinate contacts
medications: Macrolide antibiotics; supportive care
prevention: DTaP/Tdap vaccination; early treatment of contacts
treatment: Antibiotic therapy; supportive care; oxygen in infants if severe

overview: Neurological disease caused by *Clostridium tetani* toxin after contaminated wounds.
symptoms: muscle stiffness; jaw lockjaw; spasms; difficulty swallowing
cautions: Medical emergency; vaccination prevents disease
medications: Tetanus immunoglobulin; wound care; muscle relaxants
prevention: Tetanus vaccination; proper wound hygiene
treatment: Hospital care with antitoxin, antibiotics, and supportive management

overview: Mosquito-borne parasitic infection causing fever and anemia; potentially fatal.
symptoms: fever (often periodic); chills; sweating; headache; fatigue
cautions: Seek urgent care if fever in endemic area; can be life-threatening
medications: Antimalarials (artemisinin-based combinations or chloroquine per region)
prevention: Use mosquito nets; repellents; remove standing water; prophylaxis when traveling
treatment: Prompt antimalarial treatment per national protocol; supportive care for anemia or cerebral malaria

overview: Viral infection transmitted by *Aedes* mosquitoes causing fever and possible hemorrhage.
symptoms: high fever; severe headache; muscle/joint pain; rash; bleeding in severe cases
cautions: Avoid NSAIDs if dengue suspected; monitor for warning signs (bleeding, abdominal pain)
medications: Supportive only—fluids, paracetamol; no specific antiviral
prevention: Mosquito control; eliminate stagnant water; protective clothing
treatment: Supportive management; IV fluids for severe dengue; monitoring of platelets and vitals

overview: Mosquito-borne viral illness similar to dengue but marked by joint pains.
symptoms: fever; severe joint pain; rash; headache
cautions: Usually self-limited; rest joints to prevent chronic pain
medications: Supportive (analgesics, fluids); avoid NSAIDs until dengue ruled out
prevention: Mosquito control; repellents; avoid bites
treatment: Supportive care; physiotherapy for persistent arthralgia

overview: Acute diarrheal illness from *Vibrio cholerae* due to contaminated food or water.
symptoms: profuse watery diarrhoea (‘rice-water’ stools); vomiting; dehydration
cautions: Rapid dehydration can be fatal; oral or IV rehydration critical
medications: Oral rehydration salts; IV fluids; antibiotics shorten duration
prevention: Safe water; sanitation; oral cholera vaccine
treatment: Aggressive rehydration; antibiotics (doxycycline/azithromycin) per guidelines

overview: Systemic bacterial infection by *Salmonella typhi*, spread via fecal-oral route.
symptoms: prolonged fever; abdominal pain; headache; constipation or diarrhoea; rash
cautions: Seek care early; untreated cases can cause intestinal perforation
medications: Antibiotics (ceftriaxone, azithromycin, or others per sensitivity)
prevention: Safe food/water; vaccination; hygiene
treatment: Appropriate antibiotic therapy; rehydration; rest; monitor for complications

overview: Viral infection that can cause paralysis; largely eradicated by vaccination.
symptoms: fever; sore throat; weakness; in severe cases paralysis
cautions: Report immediately; ensure vaccination coverage
medications: Supportive; no specific antiviral
prevention: Oral/inactivated polio vaccination (OPV/IPV); sanitation
treatment: Supportive care; physical therapy for paralysis; respiratory support if needed

overview: Chronic infection by *Mycobacterium leprae* affecting skin, nerves, and mucosa.
symptoms: numb skin patches; muscle weakness; deformities; loss of sensation
cautions: Avoid stigma; prolonged treatment needed; notify public-health program
medications: Multidrug therapy (dapsone, rifampicin, clofazimine)
prevention: Early detection; treatment of contacts; hygiene
treatment: Multidrug therapy under national program; rehabilitation for disabilities

overview: Life-threatening organ dysfunction from dysregulated body response to infection.
symptoms: fever or hypothermia; confusion; rapid heartbeat; low BP; reduced urine
cautions: Medical emergency—requires ICU management
medications: IV fluids; antibiotics; organ support
prevention: Prompt infection control; vaccination; early treatment of infections
treatment: Hospital management with broad-spectrum antibiotics and organ support

overview: Inflammation of the appendix; surgical emergency if perforated.
symptoms: abdominal pain starting around navel shifting to right lower quadrant; nausea; fever
cautions: Seek emergency care—risk of rupture and peritonitis
medications: Pre-operative antibiotics
prevention: No prevention; early recognition critical
treatment: Surgical removal (appendectomy); antibiotics; postoperative care

overview: Protrusion of an organ or tissue through a weak spot in the muscle wall, often abdominal.
symptoms: bulge/swelling; discomfort; pain on exertion; sometimes asymptomatic
cautions: Avoid heavy lifting; seek care for sudden severe pain (strangulation)
medications: No medication cures; supportive truss temporarily
prevention: Maintain healthy weight; avoid straining; treat chronic cough/constipation
treatment: Surgical repair (herniorrhaphy/hernioplasty) is definitive treatment

overview: Low bone density increasing fracture risk, especially in older adults.
symptoms: bone pain; fractures after minor trauma; height loss
cautions: Ensure adequate calcium/vitamin D; avoid falls
medications: Calcium/vitamin D supplements; bisphosphonates; others under doctor guidance
prevention: Calcium-rich diet; weight-bearing exercise; avoid smoking/alcohol
treatment: Medications to strengthen bone; physiotherapy; fall-prevention measures

overview: Degenerative joint disease due to cartilage wear, common in knees and hips.
symptoms: joint pain; stiffness; limited mobility; crepitus
cautions: Maintain healthy weight; avoid overuse; seek physiotherapy
medications: Analgesics; NSAIDs; joint injections; physiotherapy
prevention: Weight control; low-impact exercise; ergonomics
treatment: Pain relief; physical therapy; joint replacement in severe cases

overview: Chronic autoimmune inflammatory arthritis causing joint destruction.
symptoms: morning stiffness; joint pain/swelling; fatigue
cautions: Early treatment prevents deformities; monitor drug side effects
medications: DMARDs (methotrexate, biologics) under specialist care
prevention: No specific prevention; early diagnosis improves outcome
treatment: Long-term DMARD therapy; physiotherapy; surgery for joint damage

overview: Inflammatory arthritis caused by uric-acid crystal deposition.
symptoms: sudden joint pain (often big toe); swelling; redness
cautions: Avoid alcohol excess; review medications; seek care for recurrent attacks
medications: NSAIDs; colchicine; urate-lowering therapy (allopurinol)
prevention: Limit purine-rich foods; hydration; weight management
treatment: Acute attack management with NSAIDs/colchicine; urate-lowering therapy long-term

overview: Autoimmune disease affecting multiple organs with variable symptoms.
symptoms: fatigue; joint pain; rash; fever; organ involvement
cautions: Avoid sun exposure; monitor regularly; medication adherence
medications: Corticosteroids; immunosuppressants; antimalarials (hydroxychloroquine)
prevention: Avoid UV exposure; balanced rest; vaccinations; stress control
treatment: Immunosuppressive therapy tailored to organ involvement; supportive care

overview: Chronic demyelinating CNS disorder with relapsing or progressive course.
symptoms: vision problems; limb weakness; numbness; coordination issues; fatigue
cautions: Regular neurologist follow-up; manage relapses promptly
medications: Disease-modifying therapies; corticosteroids for relapses
prevention: No known prevention; healthy lifestyle; avoid smoking
treatment: Immunomodulatory therapy; rehabilitation; symptomatic treatment

overview: Neurodegenerative disorder due to dopamine deficiency affecting movement.
symptoms: tremor; rigidity; slowness; postural instability
cautions: Medication adherence critical; avoid sudden drug withdrawal
medications: Levodopa and dopamine agonists; physiotherapy
prevention: No prevention; exercise may help delay progression
treatment: Pharmacotherapy with levodopa; deep-brain stimulation for advanced disease

overview: Progressive neurodegenerative disorder causing memory loss and cognitive decline.
symptoms: memory impairment; confusion; behavior changes; loss of daily function
cautions: Supervision needed as disease progresses; safety measures at home
medications: Cholinesterase inhibitors; memantine; supportive therapy
prevention: Brain-healthy lifestyle; mental activity; cardiovascular risk control
treatment: Medication for symptoms; supportive care; caregiver education

overview: Mood disorder with persistent sadness and loss of interest.
symptoms: low mood; fatigue; sleep changes; poor concentration; suicidal thoughts
cautions: Seek help early; suicide risk requires urgent care
medications: Antidepressants; psychotherapy
prevention: Stress management; social support; physical activity
treatment: Combination of medication and therapy; lifestyle modification; crisis support if suicidal

overview: Chronic excessive worry and tension affecting daily life.
symptoms: restlessness; irritability; muscle tension; sleep disturbance
cautions: Avoid self-medication with alcohol or sedatives; seek therapy if persistent
medications: Anxiolytics and antidepressants under medical supervision; cognitive behavioral therapy
prevention: Stress management; mindfulness; regular exercise; adequate sleep
treatment: Psychotherapy and medication tailored to severity; relaxation techniques

overview: Mood disorder with alternating depressive and manic episodes.
symptoms: periods of euphoria; decreased sleep; racing thoughts; followed by depression
cautions: Strict adherence to medication; avoid triggers like sleep deprivation
medications: Mood stabilizers (lithium, valproate) and antipsychotics
prevention: Regular sleep schedule; stress control; therapy follow-up
treatment: Medication management, psychotherapy, lifestyle structure, hospitalization for severe episodes

overview: Chronic psychotic disorder with hallucinations and delusions.
symptoms: hallucinations; delusions; social withdrawal; disorganized speech
cautions: Adherence to medication vital; relapse risk if untreated
medications: Antipsychotic medications under psychiatric supervision
prevention: Avoid substance abuse; regular follow-up; social support
treatment: Long-term antipsychotic therapy; psychosocial rehabilitation; family support

overview: Difficulty initiating or maintaining sleep leading to daytime fatigue.
symptoms: trouble falling asleep; frequent awakening; daytime sleepiness
cautions: Avoid chronic sedative use without guidance; address underlying causes
medications: Short-term hypnotics if severe; behavioral therapy for insomnia
prevention: Sleep hygiene; limit caffeine; regular schedule; relaxation
treatment: Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia; short-term medication if required

overview: Excess body fat accumulation increasing risk for chronic diseases.
symptoms: high BMI; fatigue; breathlessness; joint pain
cautions: Avoid crash diets; gradual, sustainable weight loss recommended
medications: Lifestyle modification; anti-obesity drugs or surgery when indicated
prevention: Balanced diet; regular exercise; portion control
treatment: Dietary changes, exercise, behavioral therapy, medication or bariatric surgery if severe

overview: Cluster of conditions increasing heart disease and diabetes risk.
symptoms: abdominal obesity; hypertension; high blood sugar; dyslipidemia
cautions: Early intervention prevents cardiovascular complications
medications: Lifestyle modification; treat each component medically
prevention: Healthy diet; physical activity; weight control
treatment: Diet, exercise, medications for BP, sugar, cholesterol as needed

overview: Metabolic disorder with insulin resistance causing high blood sugar.
symptoms: increased thirst; frequent urination; fatigue; blurred vision
cautions: Regular monitoring; control diet and weight; prevent complications
medications: Oral hypoglycemics; insulin if required
prevention: Healthy diet; regular exercise; weight management
treatment: Diet and medication management; monitor glucose; treat complications promptly

overview: Autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells causing insulin deficiency.
symptoms: polyuria; polydipsia; weight loss; fatigue
cautions: Requires lifelong insulin; monitor blood sugar regularly
medications: Insulin therapy; glucose monitoring
prevention: No proven prevention; early detection in at-risk groups
treatment: Insulin therapy; diet and exercise balance; education on hypoglycemia prevention

overview: Chronic elevated arterial pressure increasing risk of heart and kidney disease.
symptoms: often asymptomatic; headache; dizziness; vision changes
cautions: Regular BP checks; adherence to therapy essential
medications: Antihypertensives (ACE inhibitors, beta blockers, etc.)
prevention: Salt restriction; exercise; weight control; avoid smoking
treatment: Medication adherence; lifestyle modification; regular follow-up

overview: Elevated blood lipids increasing cardiovascular risk.
symptoms: usually asymptomatic; detected by blood test
cautions: Monitor regularly; combine medication with diet changes
medications: Statins; fibrates; diet counseling
prevention: Low-fat diet; exercise; avoid trans-fats
treatment: Lipid-lowering drugs; dietary therapy; monitoring

overview: Narrowing of heart arteries leading to angina or heart attack.
symptoms: chest pain; shortness of breath; sweating; nausea
cautions: Emergency if chest pain persists >10 min
medications: Antiplatelets; nitrates; beta blockers; statins
prevention: Healthy diet; exercise; avoid smoking; manage diabetes
treatment: Medication; angioplasty or bypass surgery; cardiac rehab

overview: Heart’s inability to pump blood effectively.
symptoms: breathlessness; swelling; fatigue; orthopnea
cautions: Monitor weight and fluid intake; seek care for worsening symptoms
medications: Diuretics; ACE inhibitors; beta blockers
prevention: Salt restriction; regular follow-up; medication adherence
treatment: Medical therapy; device or transplant in severe cases

overview: Interruption of blood flow to brain causing neurologic deficits.
symptoms: sudden weakness; speech difficulty; facial droop; vision loss
cautions: Medical emergency—time-dependent treatment
medications: Thrombolytics or antiplatelets per type; rehab
prevention: Control BP, diabetes, cholesterol; avoid smoking
treatment: Emergency care; rehabilitation; secondary prevention medications

overview: Reduced blood flow to limbs due to atherosclerosis.
symptoms: leg pain on walking; numbness; cold feet; non-healing ulcers
cautions: Avoid smoking; foot care critical
medications: Antiplatelets; statins; exercise therapy
prevention: Smoking cessation; exercise; control diabetes
treatment: Medical therapy; angioplasty/bypass for severe ischemia

overview: Formation of blood clot in deep veins, usually legs.
symptoms: leg swelling; pain; redness; warmth
cautions: Risk of pulmonary embolism—seek urgent care
medications: Anticoagulants; compression stockings
prevention: Mobility during travel; hydration; manage risk factors
treatment: Anticoagulant therapy; monitor INR; treat underlying cause

overview: Blockage of lung artery by clot from leg veins (DVT).
symptoms: sudden breathlessness; chest pain; cough; rapid heart rate
cautions: Life-threatening—emergency treatment
medications: Anticoagulants; thrombolytics if massive
prevention: Prevent DVT; mobility; compression stockings
treatment: Hospital management with anticoagulation and oxygen therapy

overview: Severe allergic reaction causing airway and circulatory compromise.
symptoms: sudden swelling; difficulty breathing; hypotension; hives
cautions: Immediate emergency; use epinephrine auto-injector if available
medications: Epinephrine IM; IV fluids; steroids; antihistamines
prevention: Avoid known allergens; carry epinephrine auto-injector
treatment: Emergency management with epinephrine; monitor for biphasic reaction

overview: Neurological disorder with recurrent seizures.
symptoms: convulsions; loss of consciousness; confusion; tongue bite
cautions: Do not restrain during seizure; ensure medication adherence
medications: Antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) tailored to type
prevention: Avoid triggers; regular medication; adequate sleep
treatment: Antiepileptic medication; surgery for refractory cases; lifestyle safety education

overview: Inflammation of meninges due to infection (bacterial or viral).
symptoms: fever; headache; neck stiffness; photophobia; altered sensorium
cautions: Medical emergency; hospital care required
medications: Antibiotics or antivirals depending on cause
prevention: Vaccination (Hib, meningococcal); hygiene; early treatment
treatment: Prompt IV antibiotics; supportive care; isolation if bacterial

overview: Inflammation of brain tissue, often viral in origin.
symptoms: fever; seizures; confusion; headache; altered consciousness
cautions: Urgent hospitalization needed
medications: Antivirals (acyclovir for HSV); supportive ICU care
prevention: Vaccination (Japanese encephalitis etc.); vector control
treatment: Hospital supportive management; antivirals when indicated

overview: Deficient thyroid hormone production slowing metabolism.
symptoms: fatigue; weight gain; cold intolerance; dry skin
cautions: Regular thyroid monitoring; avoid abrupt medication changes
medications: Levothyroxine replacement under supervision
prevention: Iodine-adequate diet; screening in high-risk groups
treatment: Thyroid hormone replacement; lifelong monitoring

overview: Excess thyroid hormone production causing hypermetabolic state.
symptoms: weight loss; tremor; heat intolerance; palpitations
cautions: Monitor cardiac status; avoid abrupt cessation of drugs
medications: Antithyroid medications; beta blockers; radioiodine or surgery
prevention: Regular thyroid checks; stress management
treatment: Medication or radioiodine ablation; surgery for large goiter

overview: Excess cortisol levels from endogenous or exogenous causes.
symptoms: weight gain (truncal); moon face; hypertension; striae
cautions: Identify and treat underlying cause; monitor glucose/BP
medications: Reduce corticosteroid dose if drug-induced; surgery for adrenal/pituitary cause
prevention: Avoid unnecessary steroid use; manage stress
treatment: Surgical or medical correction of hormone excess; manage complications

overview: Adrenal insufficiency causing cortisol/aldosterone deficiency.
symptoms: fatigue; weight loss; low BP; skin pigmentation
cautions: Requires lifelong hormone replacement; stress dosing during illness
medications: Hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone replacement
prevention: Prompt treatment of infections; carry steroid alert card
treatment: Hormone replacement therapy; crisis management with IV steroids and fluids

overview: Pregnancy-related hypertension with organ involvement; can progress to eclampsia.
symptoms: high BP; swelling; headache; visual changes; proteinuria
cautions: Medical emergency in pregnancy; monitor closely
medications: Antihypertensives; magnesium sulfate; delivery is definitive
prevention: Antenatal care; monitor BP; manage risk factors
treatment: Hospital monitoring; control BP; plan timely delivery

overview: Implantation of embryo outside uterus, usually in fallopian tube.
symptoms: abdominal pain; missed period; vaginal bleeding; dizziness
cautions: Life-threatening rupture possible; emergency evaluation needed
medications: Methotrexate (medical) or surgical management
prevention: Early pregnancy scan; treat pelvic infections
treatment: Medical or surgical removal of ectopic tissue; supportive care

overview: Malignant tumor of breast tissue; wide spectrum from localized to metastatic disease.
symptoms: breast lump; skin dimpling; nipple discharge; breast pain
cautions: Early detection via screening improves outcomes; seek evaluation for new lumps
medications: Surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, targeted therapy depending on stage
prevention: Regular screening (mammography) as recommended; self-awareness; reduce modifiable risks
treatment: Multimodal treatment by oncology team: surgery ± chemo/radiation/targeted therapy per guidelines

overview: Malignancy of lung tissue with smoking as major risk factor.
symptoms: persistent cough; hemoptysis; weight loss; breathlessness
cautions: Urgent evaluation for persistent respiratory symptoms; smoking cessation crucial
medications: Surgery, chemotherapy, targeted therapy, immunotherapy depending on type and stage
prevention: Avoid smoking; reduce occupational exposures; screening in high-risk groups
treatment: Stage-based therapy: surgery, chemo, targeted drugs, immunotherapy; palliative care when needed

overview: Cancer of colon or rectum often preceded by polyps.
symptoms: change in bowel habits; rectal bleeding; weight loss; abdominal pain
cautions: Screening reduces mortality; seek care for persistent bleeding or changes
medications: Surgery, chemotherapy, targeted treatments; radiotherapy for rectal tumors
prevention: Regular screening (colonoscopy) per guidelines; healthy diet, activity
treatment: Surgical resection with adjuvant therapy as indicated; surveillance after treatment

overview: Common cancer in older men, often slow-growing.
symptoms: urinary symptoms; hematuria; sometimes asymptomatic
cautions: Screening debated—discuss PSA testing with clinician
medications: Surgery, radiation, hormonal therapy, active surveillance for low-risk cases
prevention: Healthy lifestyle; informed decision about screening
treatment: Active surveillance for low-grade disease; radical therapy for higher-risk disease

overview: Malignancy of blood-forming tissues causing abnormal white cells.
symptoms: fatigue; fever; recurrent infections; bleeding
cautions: Urgent hematology referral; risk of rapid deterioration
medications: Chemotherapy, targeted therapies, possible bone marrow transplant
prevention: No specific prevention; monitor high-risk patients
treatment: Systemic chemotherapy; targeted agents; hematopoietic stem cell transplant in selected cases

overview: Cancer of the lymphatic system (Hodgkin/non-Hodgkin varieties).
symptoms: painless lymphadenopathy; fever; night sweats; weight loss
cautions: Prompt oncologic assessment needed for persistent lymph node enlargement
medications: Chemotherapy, immunotherapy, radiotherapy depending on type/stage
prevention: No routine prevention; vaccination where relevant
treatment: Combination chemo/immunotherapy ± radiotherapy; long-term follow-up

overview: Malignant tumor of melanocytes; can metastasize quickly.
symptoms: changing mole; irregular border; color variation; bleeding
cautions: Early detection critical; avoid tanning; seek dermatology review of suspicious lesions
medications: Surgical excision; immunotherapy/targeted therapy for advanced disease
prevention: Sun protection (SPF, clothing), avoid tanning beds; regular skin checks
treatment: Wide local excision for localized disease; systemic therapy for metastatic melanoma

overview: Common skin cancer that rarely metastasizes but causes local damage.
symptoms: pearly nodule; ulceration; bleeding; slow-growing lesion
cautions: Early removal prevents local tissue loss
medications: Surgical excision, Mohs surgery, topical therapies for superficial lesions
prevention: Sun protection and skin surveillance
treatment: Surgical removal; topical or destructive methods for small lesions; follow-up

overview: (Listed separately to emphasize seriousness) Pigmented malignant skin tumor with metastatic potential.
symptoms: irregular, changing pigmented lesion
cautions: Urgent dermatology referral for suspicious lesions
medications: Surgical excision; immunotherapy or targeted agents for advanced disease
prevention: Sun protection; regular skin checks
treatment: Early excision; adjuvant or systemic therapy when indicated

overview: Air in pleural space causing lung collapse; spontaneous or traumatic.
symptoms: sudden unilateral chest pain; shortness of breath
cautions: Large or tension pneumothorax is an emergency
medications: Observation for small pneumothorax; needle aspiration or chest tube for larger
prevention: Avoid high-risk behaviors (deep sea diving, smoking) where applicable
treatment: Oxygen and observation for small; needle decompression/chest tube for larger; surgery for recurrent cases

overview: Pneumothorax occurring on background lung disease (eg COPD).
symptoms: sudden breathlessness; pleuritic chest pain
cautions: Higher risk of severe respiratory compromise
medications: Hospital management often required
prevention: Optimize underlying lung disease; smoking cessation
treatment: Chest tube drainage; surgical pleurodesis in recurrent cases

overview: Inflammation of pleura causing sharp chest pain with breathing.
symptoms: sharp pleuritic chest pain; cough; breathlessness
cautions: Evaluate for underlying causes (infection, PE, autoimmune)
medications: Treat underlying cause; analgesics; sometimes steroids
prevention: Avoid respiratory infections; seek care for persistent chest pain
treatment: Treat underlying disease (antibiotics for infection), analgesia, pleural procedures if needed

overview: Occupational lung disease due to inhaled dust (eg silica, coal).
symptoms: progressive breathlessness; chronic cough; reduced exercise tolerance
cautions: Prevent exposure; occupational health surveillance
medications: Supportive care; prevent further exposure
prevention: Workplace dust control; PPE; smoking cessation
treatment: Avoid exposure; symptomatic management; monitor for complications

overview: Spontaneous collapse of lung in otherwise healthy individuals (often tall thin young men).
symptoms: sudden chest pain; dyspnea
cautions: Recurrence risk; smoking increases risk
medications: Observation or intervention depending on size and symptoms
prevention: Avoid smoking; seek care for sudden chest pain
treatment: Conservative management for small, intervention for larger cases; surgical repair if recurrent

overview: Scarring of lung tissue causing progressive breathlessness.
symptoms: progressive dyspnea; dry cough; fatigue
cautions: Specialist referral needed; progressive disease with poor prognosis
medications: Antifibrotic drugs in selected cases; oxygen therapy
prevention: Avoid smoking; manage exposures; vaccination
treatment: Antifibrotic therapy, pulmonary rehab, oxygen; transplant in select patients

overview: Air enters pleural space due to chest trauma.
symptoms: chest pain; breathlessness; signs of trauma
cautions: Potentially life-threatening; urgent management
medications: Chest tube drainage; surgical repair if needed
prevention: Use of seatbelts, protective equipment in high-risk jobs/sports
treatment: Emergency chest decompression/chest tube; surgery for major trauma

overview: Severe abdominal pain from multiple causes requiring urgent evaluation.
symptoms: severe abdominal pain; vomiting; fever; guarding
cautions: Urgent surgical or medical evaluation required
medications: Treat cause-specific (antibiotics, surgery, supportive care)
prevention: Early medical review for severe pain
treatment: Diagnosis-driven care—may require surgery (eg perforation, appendicitis)

overview: Inflammation of appendix needing prompt evaluation and often surgery.
symptoms: periumbilical pain migrating to right lower quadrant; nausea; fever
cautions: Risk of perforation—urgent surgical assessment
medications: Pre-op antibiotics; analgesia
prevention: No prevention; early recognition key
treatment: Appendectomy (laparoscopic/open) and antibiotics

overview: Protrusion of organ through weakened abdominal wall; watch for strangulation.
symptoms: visible bulge; pain with lifting; irreducible mass in strangulation
cautions: Seek urgent care if irreducible and painful
medications: Surgical repair is definitive
prevention: Avoid heavy lifting; smoking cessation to improve healing
treatment: Elective or emergency surgical repair depending on symptoms/strangulation

overview: Inflammation of peritoneum commonly from perforation or infection.
symptoms: severe abdominal pain; guarding; fever; distension
cautions: Life-threatening—urgent surgery often required
medications: Antibiotics and surgical source control
prevention: Early treatment of intra-abdominal infections; hygiene in procedures
treatment: Emergency laparotomy/laparascopy for source control + antibiotics

overview: Lung infection due to inhaled gastric contents or oropharyngeal secretions.
symptoms: fever; cough; foul sputum; breathlessness
cautions: At-risk patients (reduced consciousness) need prevention measures
medications: Antibiotics with anaerobic coverage when indicated
prevention: Swallowing assessment in high-risk patients; positioning
treatment: Antibiotic therapy, supportive care, address swallowing dysfunction

overview: Fluid in middle ear without acute infection causing hearing loss.
symptoms: hearing difficulties; aural fullness; often no fever
cautions: Evaluate in children—can affect speech development
medications: Observation or grommet insertion if persistent
prevention: Treat upper respiratory infections promptly; avoid smoke exposure
treatment: Watchful waiting; ENT referral for persistent effusion and hearing loss

overview: Viral lower respiratory tract infection in infants (eg RSV).
symptoms: wheezing; cough; nasal congestion; difficulty feeding
cautions: Young infants may need monitoring for respiratory failure
medications: Supportive care; oxygen if hypoxic
prevention: Hand hygiene; avoid sick contacts; breastfeeding
treatment: Supportive therapy; oxygen and hydration; hospitalization if severe

overview: Common cause of bronchiolitis and pneumonia in infants and elderly.
symptoms: cough; wheeze; fever; breathing difficulty
cautions: Monitor infants closely; high-risk neonates may need prophylaxis
medications: Supportive care; prophylactic monoclonal antibodies for high-risk infants
prevention: Hand hygiene; avoid exposure of infants to sick contacts
treatment: Supportive care; oxygen and hydration; monoclonal prophylaxis in selected infants

overview: Inflammation of inner ear causing vertigo and hearing changes.
symptoms: vertigo; hearing loss; nausea; imbalance
cautions: Seek ENT assessment for severe vestibular symptoms
medications: Symptomatic therapy for vertigo; treat underlying infection if present
prevention: Avoid head injury; seek prompt care for severe vertigo
treatment: Vestibular suppressants for acute symptoms; rehabilitation; treat cause

overview: Median nerve compression at wrist causing hand symptoms.
symptoms: numbness/tingling in thumb-index-middle fingers; night symptoms; weakness
cautions: Early wrist splinting can help; surgery for severe weakness
medications: Wrist splints; NSAIDs; steroid injection; surgical decompression
prevention: Ergonomic adjustments; wrist exercises
treatment: Conservative measures; surgical release for refractory cases

overview: Tear of shoulder tendons causing pain and limited movement.
symptoms: shoulder pain; weakness raising arm; night pain
cautions: Seek specialist if loss of function or severe pain
medications: Physiotherapy; NSAIDs; steroid injection; surgery for full-thickness tears
prevention: Avoid repetitive overhead strain; strengthen shoulder muscles
treatment: Physiotherapy; arthroscopic repair for significant tears

overview: Painful or abnormal menstrual bleeding affecting quality of life.
symptoms: cramping pelvic pain; heavy bleeding; irregular cycles
cautions: Evaluate heavy bleeding to exclude serious causes
medications: NSAIDs for pain; hormonal contraceptives for cycle control
prevention: Healthy lifestyle; track cycles; seek care if heavy or irregular bleeding
treatment: Analgesics, hormonal therapy, investigate and treat underlying pathology

overview: Ectopic growth of endometrial tissue causing pelvic pain and infertility.
symptoms: severe dysmenorrhea; dyspareunia; infertility; pelvic pain
cautions: Specialist management for pain and fertility issues
medications: Hormonal therapies; analgesics; surgical excision when needed
prevention: Early evaluation of pelvic pain; fertility planning
treatment: Medical suppression or laparoscopic excision; multidisciplinary care for fertility

overview: Malignant tumor arising from pancreatic tissue, often diagnosed late due to vague symptoms; frequently aggressive with poor prognosis.
symptoms: progressive weight loss; persistent upper abdominal/back pain; jaundice; anorexia; new-onset diabetes in some cases
cautions: Early specialist referral for suspicious symptoms; rapid evaluation for painless jaundice or rapidly worsening pain
medications: Multimodal oncology therapies (surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy) determined by stage; symptom-directed analgesia
prevention: Smoking cessation; maintain healthy weight; manage chronic pancreatitis risk factors
treatment: Stage-based care: surgical resection for resectable disease, systemic chemotherapy for advanced stages, palliative care for symptom control

overview: Malignancy of ovarian tissue, often presents late with non-specific symptoms, risk increases with age and certain genetic factors.
symptoms: abdominal bloating; early satiety; pelvic pain; urinary frequency; unexplained weight changes
cautions: Early gynecologic evaluation for persistent bloating or pelvic symptoms; family history may warrant genetic counseling
medications: Surgery (debulking), platinum-based chemotherapy, targeted therapies for selected subtypes
prevention: Risk-reducing strategies include oral contraceptives (in some cases) and surveillance for high-risk individuals
treatment: Surgical staging and cytoreduction combined with chemotherapy; maintenance targeted therapy for some patients

overview: Relatively uncommon malignancy in young men, often highly treatable when detected early.
symptoms: painless testicular mass or swelling; heaviness; dull ache in scrotum/abdomen
cautions: Urgent urology assessment for any testicular lumps; self-examination awareness recommended
medications: Orchiectomy is diagnostic and therapeutic; chemotherapy and radiotherapy for advanced disease
prevention: Self-examination awareness; prompt evaluation of lumps
treatment: Surgical removal (radical inguinal orchiectomy) followed by stage-adapted chemo/radiotherapy and surveillance

overview: Malignancy originating from urothelial cells; often presents with visible blood in urine.
symptoms: painless hematuria; urinary frequency; urgency; pelvic pain in advanced disease
cautions: Any visible blood in urine requires urgent evaluation; smoking is a major risk factor
medications: Surgery, intravesical therapies (for superficial disease), systemic therapy for advanced disease
prevention: Smoking cessation; avoid occupational exposures to carcinogens; hydration
treatment: Transurethral resection for superficial tumors; cystectomy for invasive disease; systemic chemo/immunotherapy as indicated

overview: Malignant tumor of the renal parenchyma; may be incidental on imaging or present with hematuria.
symptoms: blood in urine; flank pain; palpable mass; unexplained weight loss
cautions: Prompt imaging if hematuria occurs; manage cardiovascular risk factors
medications: Surgical resection (partial or radical nephrectomy); targeted agents and immunotherapy for advanced disease
prevention: Avoid smoking; control hypertension; maintain healthy weight
treatment: Nephron-sparing surgery when possible; systemic therapy for metastatic disease; surveillance for small renal masses

overview: A subset of pancreatic tumors arising from hormone-secreting cells, variable behavior from indolent to aggressive.
symptoms: hormone-related symptoms if functional (hypoglycemia, gastrin-related ulcers) or non-specific abdominal pain and weight loss
cautions: Specialist endocrine-oncology evaluation required; biochemical testing for hormonal syndromes
medications: Surgery for localized disease; somatostatin analogues, targeted therapy or peptide receptor radionuclide therapy for advanced disease
prevention: Regular monitoring in genetic syndromes; smoking cessation
treatment: Surgical resection for localized tumors; medical and targeted therapies for metastatic or functional tumors

overview: Mucosal growths in the colon/rectum; some evolve into cancer over years if left untreated.
symptoms: often asymptomatic; may cause occult or visible bleeding; change in bowel habits
cautions: Screening and timely removal reduces colorectal cancer risk
medications: Polypectomy during colonoscopy; surveillance intervals based on pathology
prevention: Regular colonoscopic screening per guidelines; healthy diet and exercise
treatment: Endoscopic polypectomy for most polyps; surgical resection for large or invasive lesions

overview: Malignancy of the esophagus associated with dysphagia and weight loss; two main histologies: squamous and adenocarcinoma.
symptoms: progressive difficulty swallowing solids then liquids; weight loss; odynophagia; hoarseness in advanced cases
cautions: Urgent evaluation for progressive dysphagia; consider endoscopic assessment and biopsy
medications: Multimodal therapy: surgery, chemoradiation, stenting for palliation
prevention: Avoid tobacco and excessive alcohol; manage reflux disease and Barrett’s esophagus
treatment: Curative-intent surgery +/- neoadjuvant chemoradiation for localized disease; palliative stenting or systemic therapy for advanced disease

overview: Malignancy of thyroid tissue; many subtypes, often detected as a thyroid nodule with generally favorable prognosis for common forms.
symptoms: painless thyroid nodule; hoarseness, difficulty swallowing if large or locally invasive
cautions: Fine-needle aspiration for suspicious nodules; urgent evaluation for rapidly growing nodules
medications: Surgical thyroidectomy, radioactive iodine for some subtypes, thyroid hormone suppression therapy
prevention: Avoid unnecessary radiation exposure to neck; surveillance of nodules
treatment: Surgical removal guided by subtype; adjuvant radioactive iodine for certain differentiated cancers; long-term endocrinology follow-up

overview: Excess parathyroid hormone causing hypercalcemia with multi-system effects, primary or secondary forms.
symptoms: fatigue; polyuria; kidney stones; bone pain; neurocognitive symptoms
cautions: Monitor calcium; seek specialist evaluation for persistent hypercalcemia
medications: Surgical removal for primary disease; medical management for secondary causes
prevention: Address vitamin D deficiency; monitor calcium and kidney function
treatment: Parathyroidectomy for selected patients; medical optimization and monitoring for non-surgical candidates

overview: Rare catecholamine-secreting adrenal tumor causing episodic hypertension and sympathetic symptoms.
symptoms: paroxysmal headache; sweating; palpitations; episodic hypertension; anxiety-like symptoms
cautions: Preoperative biochemical diagnosis critical; control blood pressure before surgery
medications: Adrenalectomy is treatment of choice; pre-op alpha-blockade to prevent hypertensive crisis
prevention: Genetic counseling for familial syndromes; surveillance in at-risk individuals
treatment: Surgical removal with careful pre-op preparation; lifelong follow-up for recurrence in some cases

overview: Inadequate cortisol production due to pituitary or exogenous steroid suppression, causing fatigue and hypotension.
symptoms: fatigue; weakness; weight loss; low blood pressure; salt craving in primary forms
cautions: Risk of adrenal crisis during stress or infection—carry alert and seek urgent care
medications: Glucocorticoid replacement therapy; treat underlying pituitary disease when possible
prevention: Avoid abrupt steroid withdrawal; medical alert identification
treatment: Lifelong hormone replacement for chronic cases; emergency IV steroids for adrenal crisis

overview: Inherited bleeding disorder due to factor VIII deficiency causing prolonged bleeding and joint hemorrhages.
symptoms: excessive bleeding after injury; joint swelling and pain from hemarthroses; easy bruising
cautions: Prompt specialist hematology care for bleeding; avoid certain medications that increase bleeding risk
medications: Replacement of missing clotting factor concentrates (on-demand or prophylactic) under hematology guidance
prevention: Genetic counseling; avoid NSAIDs and anticoagulants unless advised
treatment: Factor replacement therapy for bleeding and prophylaxis; physiotherapy for joint management

overview: Common inherited bleeding disorder due to quantitative/qualitative vWF deficiency causing mucocutaneous bleeding.
symptoms: nosebleeds; heavy menstrual bleeding; easy bruising; prolonged bleeding after procedures
cautions: Pre-procedural planning with hematology for surgeries or dental work
medications: Desmopressin or vWF concentrates for significant bleeding as guided by specialist
prevention: Avoid medications increasing bleeding risk; appropriate hemostatic planning for procedures
treatment: Desmopressin for responsive patients; vWF concentrate infusion for severe cases; supportive care

overview: Genetic predisposition to abnormal blood clotting increasing risk for DVT/PE, examples include Factor V Leiden.
symptoms: recurrent DVT or PE; unexplained thrombosis especially at young age
cautions: Family screening and specialist advice for anticoagulation decisions
medications: Anticoagulation for acute events and in some high-risk situations
prevention: Avoid prolonged immobility; manage other clotting risks (smoking, obesity)
treatment: Anticoagulant therapy for thrombotic events; individualized long-term prophylaxis decisions

overview: Bacterial zoonosis from *Leptospira* causing febrile illness, can progress to multi-organ involvement.
symptoms: fever; myalgia (notably calf pain); conjunctival suffusion; headache; jaundice in severe cases
cautions: Consider exposure history (floodwater, animals); early antibiotics reduce severity
medications: Antibiotics (doxycycline/penicillin) when indicated; supportive care for organ dysfunction
prevention: Avoid contaminated water; protective measures for high-risk occupations
treatment: Early antibiotic therapy and supportive management for severe renal/hepatic involvement

overview: Zoonotic bacterial infection acquired from unpasteurized dairy or contact with infected animals causing chronic systemic symptoms.
symptoms: fever, sweats; arthralgia; malaise; hepatosplenomegaly; chronic fatigue
cautions: Consider occupation and dietary exposures; prolonged antibiotic courses often needed
medications: Combination antibiotic therapy (doxycycline + rifampicin or aminoglycoside) under specialist guidance
prevention: Avoid unpasteurized dairy products; occupational precautions for animal handlers
treatment: Prolonged combination antibiotic regimens and monitoring for relapse

overview: Parasitic infection acquired from freshwater snails causing urinary or intestinal disease with chronic complications.
symptoms: haematuria (urinary species); abdominal pain; diarrhoea; hepatosplenomegaly in chronic disease
cautions: Consider travel and freshwater exposure history; treat early to avoid chronic complications
medications: Praziquantel is the mainstay antiparasitic treatment
prevention: Avoid swimming in contaminated freshwater in endemic areas; public health control of snails
treatment: Antiparasitic therapy (praziquantel) and management of chronic complications such as bladder pathology

overview: Protozoal intestinal infection causing prolonged diarrhoea and malabsorption in some cases.
symptoms: watery foul-smelling diarrhoea; bloating; abdominal cramps; weight loss; steatorrhea
cautions: Consider recent travel or contaminated water exposure; treat persistent cases to prevent malabsorption
medications: Antiparasitic agents (metronidazole or tinidazole) when indicated
prevention: Safe drinking water; boil/treat water when traveling; good hygiene
treatment: Antiparasitic therapy plus rehydration and nutritional support for chronic cases

overview: Soil-transmitted helminth infection that can persist and cause severe disease in immunosuppressed hosts.
symptoms: abdominal pain; diarrhoea; skin rash; cough; potential hyperinfection in immunosuppressed
cautions: Be vigilant in immunosuppressed patients or migrants from endemic areas; treat before immunosuppression when possible
medications: Ivermectin is main treatment; specialist advice for complicated cases
prevention: Sanitation and wearing footwear in endemic regions; screening in migrants
treatment: Anthelmintic therapy with ivermectin; manage hyperinfection aggressively with supportive care

overview: Small vessel inflammatory condition often post-infectious or drug-related causing palpable purpura and organ symptoms.
symptoms: palpable purpura on lower limbs; joint pain; abdominal pain; hematuria if renal involvement
cautions: Identify and stop offending drugs; investigate systemic involvement
medications: Treat underlying cause; corticosteroids or immunosuppressants for severe systemic disease
prevention: Avoid triggers and manage infections promptly
treatment: Supportive care for cutaneous disease; immunosuppression for systemic vasculitis depending on severity

overview: Autoimmune connective tissue disease characterized by skin thickening and multi-organ fibrosis.
symptoms: skin tightness; Raynaud phenomenon; dysphagia; interstitial lung disease; renal crisis in severe cases
cautions: Requires multidisciplinary care; monitor for pulmonary and renal complications
medications: Immunosuppressive agents, vasoactive drugs for Raynaud, organ-specific therapy
prevention: Avoid smoking; early screening for pulmonary hypertension and ILD
treatment: Organ-targeted therapy (immunosuppression for lung disease), vascular agents for digital ischemia, supportive multidisciplinary care

overview: Autoimmune neuromuscular junction disorder causing fluctuating muscle weakness worsened by exertion.
symptoms: ptosis; diplopia; fluctuating limb weakness; bulbar symptoms (dysarthria, dysphagia)
cautions: Risk of myasthenic crisis with respiratory compromise—rapid specialist care needed
medications: Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors, immunosuppressants, and thymectomy in selected patients
prevention: Avoid medications that worsen neuromuscular transmission; infection prevention
treatment: Symptomatic therapy (pyridostigmine), immunosuppression for severe disease, thymectomy for thymoma-associated or refractory cases

overview: Acute immune-mediated polyneuropathy causing rapidly progressive ascending weakness and potential respiratory failure.
symptoms: ascending weakness; areflexia; paresthesias; variable autonomic dysfunction
cautions: Hospitalize for monitoring of respiratory and autonomic function; may progress rapidly
medications: IV immunoglobulin or plasmapheresis are effective when started early
prevention: Infection prevention; early recognition after antecedent infection
treatment: Urgent supportive care with respiratory monitoring, IVIG or plasmapheresis, rehabilitation

overview: Complex, multisystem condition characterized by profound fatigue and post-exertional malaise not relieved by rest.
symptoms: debilitating fatigue; post-exertional malaise; cognitive dysfunction; unrefreshing sleep
cautions: Multidisciplinary management recommended; validate patient symptoms
medications: Symptomatic management (sleep hygiene, graded activity cautiously), CBT may help some patients
prevention: Pacing and energy management strategies; avoid overexertion
treatment: Supportive multidisciplinary care focusing on symptom management and pacing

overview: Chronic pain syndrome with widespread musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and sleep disturbance.
symptoms: widespread chronic pain; tender points; fatigue; sleep problems; cognitive symptoms
